I'm going to ultimately say no.  And I feel bad saying that, because what the game does well, it does very well.  But what it does badly, it does [i]disastrously.[/i]

The setting and storytelling are excellent.  Really, really excellent.  It's a complex story with lots of nuanced interactions between a lot of different factions with their own outlooks and agendas.  You fluidly act between them without really locking yourself into a side, and there are plenty of different layers to how the end can play out depending on what you did.  The NPCs are scripted well.  Dungeons are full of neat gimmicks; automated bio-defenses that can be brute forced, disabled, or even "convinced" to aid you.  A couple areas have environmental hazards that are pretty unusual for Spiderweb.  The game just generally feels very believably alive in a way a lot of games don't.

The Shaping gimmick to create your own minions is, at its core, brilliant.  You effectively create them by spending from your [i]max[/i] MP, and can only regain it when the minion dies or you reabsorb it.  They level up over time, so they're effectively as disposable as you make them, and you can shoot for quality or quantity as you feel like, leaving as much or little of a casting pool for yourself as you judge.  It's a really interesting system and it gels perfectly with the story, aesthetic, and themes of playing God that the game centers around.

Unfortunately, it's an excruciating slog to actually play through to [i]see[/i] that story.  The interface and combat is horrendously clunky and dated even as far as Spiderweb games go, but honestly that's the least of the problems.

The main issue with the game is that enemy attacks have a massive, massive damage range.  Throughout the entire game everyday enemies will be launching attacks that do anywhere from 0 damage (not necessarily a miss -- null damage) to almost twice your max HP for an instant game over.  I wish that was an exaggeration.  Armor has a marginal effect at best, and the numbers are so explosively wide that you practically need statistical analysis to tell an average reduction is happening at all.  And the whole time, your own damage output is generally pretty predictable with much narrower ranges, so you know the dev could've scaled incoming damage properly too and just...didn't.  It's a numbers game and you don't have or ever really get all of the numbers that make it particularly reliable.

It seems like the game expects you to leverage your created minions to tank these hits for you, but it doesn't really work.  Most creatures' movement range is greater than your sight radius, and unlike later Spiderweb games there is no action penalty for moving around opposing units or attempting to disengage -- so everything just sort of randomly picks a target.  Most of the game is out in the open or in wide spaces that are impossible to bottleneck melee enemies, and even in tight spaces permittivity is wonky because movement isn't grid-based and enemies will usually squeeze through.  Ranged attackers will just shoot you freely.  Even if you just run around a corner out of line of sight and leave your minions in place, enemies will often ignore your minions and pursue you.  And in the event your minion does eat the hit, everything you create up to and including explicitly tanky Thaads are very nearly as prone to instant death as you are, forcing you to run back to town to regain the half-to-a-third of the magic bar you had to semi-permanently invest and recreate it.

This ends up turning the whole game, every single time combat initiates for a 30-odd hour game, into a quicksave-scum slog that make old-school classics like Baldur's Gate feel downright generous.  With how broken the combat is, I just can't recommend it.  I feel like the fluid faction interplay is the only reason Geneforge wasn't better off as a book.  Because I'm gonna level with you here -- it would be a [i]really kickass book.[/i]

从Geneforge2穿越回来的忠告：请直接从2代开始玩起，相当于资料片，无论是装备还是技能都丰富了很多，并且不影响剧情的理解。这1代直接忽略吧，装备库太烂了，根本没有玩下去的动力。另外，虽然这游戏有大量巨量海量天量的文本，但90%的你都可以直接无视，因为基本都是描写环境的。只看和npc对话（双引号里的内容）即可，只看和任务相关的内容，玩到中期自然就知道这游戏大概在讲什么了，这系列没你想象中那么难入门。

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
这游戏最大的特色可不是剧情，而是战斗系统。这战斗系统算是非常新颖的，我以前从未见过。

你看着以为是《暗黑2》那种APRG模式，打起来才发现原来是回合制，而且是半回合制——你在地图上闲逛，碰到一个敌人，此时会自动进入战斗，而且不是像《英雄无敌3》系列那样加载一个另外的战斗场景，而是直接在当前的场景直接进行回合制战斗(有点像《神界原罪2》的那种感觉)。

战斗场景，你拥有8个行动点，走一步消耗1个行动点，攻击消耗5个行动点，吃药消耗3个行动点，当你的行动点消耗完毕，那么你的回合结束，轮到对方行动，对方也是按照相同规则来行动。

最大的特色来了：如果在战斗中发现打不过对方，可以用大部分的行动点移动，脱离敌人的视野，比如移动7次，只留下1个行动点，干什么？按f键切换状态！只要你脱离了敌人的视野，那么就可以取消战斗状态，切换成闲逛状态，闲逛状态是不存在行动点的概念的，可以一直移动。也就是说，你在战斗状态已经和对方拉开了7格距离，而因为战斗是回合制的，你在移动，对方却无法行动；一旦到了闲逛状态，虽然你和对方都能移动了，但是距离已经拉开了，再饶几下树林，就能轻松甩开对方的追杀。

上面说的是战斗切闲逛。其实闲逛也可以主动切为战斗。这个游戏是存在出手的快慢的，如果你在闲逛中和敌人相遇（只要和敌人相遇，就被迫切换成战斗状态），你反映速度不够快，那就会被敌人先攻击。但是如果你利用了SL大法，知道前面有敌人；或者远远就看到了敌人，那么就可以提前按f键进入战斗状态，这样就可以先手攻击。另外，闲逛状态的移动速度较慢，而战斗状态的移动速度很快，很多时候都开着战斗状态来跑地图。

这种可以随时切换闲逛、战斗的半回合制战斗模式是十分新颖的，我想它应该就是该游戏最大的特色。还有一个有趣的地方，就是当你在友军npc面前偷它们东西被发现的时候，它们会愤怒。这样多搞几次，或者直接杀人（这游戏所有的npc无论敌我中立都可以杀），那么它们也全村都变成敌对势力。。。所以，经常买东西不付钱的我，已经不知道屠了几个村了。。。哈哈。。

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

上面说了一些优点，其实是前几个小时的体验。但是新鲜劲一过，当我探索了十几个村庄（大概是全游戏的1/4~1/3）后，就失去了继续玩下去的动力。战斗系统虽然不错，却也不能弥补游戏性的不足。有人说这游戏的剧情可以加分，大概说的是后面的内容，不过我是没机会体验到了。但即使剧情好，我也不想推荐，毕竟作者花那么多时间去构建技能属性系统（而不仅是剧情），应该是想以游戏性作为卖点的，既然我认为游戏性不足，那么也理应给不推荐。下面说说这游戏的缺点。

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

首先，这游戏的平衡性做的不好。上面说了，打不过就跑，然后躲到角落治疗，治疗完再去打，这样应该没什么难度。可有一种情况非常讨厌，就是一群怪物一拥而上，根本没法玩。有好几次我看到一个落单的怪物，手动f键开启战斗，先手攻击了一下，结果从我视野外瞬间跑出5只怪物来攻击我，然后我他妈就被这5只怪物追着满地图跑。。。。十分恶心。我用的是法师，这法师居然没有AOE。。所以1v1根本不虚任何人，一旦碰到抱团的，就跟孙子一样，一个字，跑！！


其次，这游戏的装备系统也做的很差。我玩了6个钟头，身上的装备根本就没变过，直到探索了十几个村庄后才更新了2件装备。不是因为我买不起，我的钱多的根本不知道怎么花，而是NPC卖的全部都是垃圾，野怪爆的也都是垃圾。你会发现，你从头到尾看到的的物品基本就是那二十几个。。。实在是匮乏了点。NPC不卖药。我治疗自己基本都是靠魔法，而补充魔力是回到特定的村庄，经常这样跑，很浪费时间。虽然战利品偶尔会爆出一些治疗药剂，可实在很少。

最后，培养系统做的也不好。都已经升到了10级，依然被抱团碾压，依然很辛苦地hit and run，依然被敌人一次攻击少1/3血，依然省吃俭用跑魔法池回复。。。总之，我已经找不到升级的快感了。因为无论我怎么升级攻击，还是经常出现一次杀不死怪物剩几滴血的情况。。。就算我每个村庄的NPC全部扫荡干净，疯狂升级，每次杀死一个怪物需要的次数却越来越多。。。

所以，我玩不下去了。

综上所述，对于一款很难有动力玩下去的游戏，即使它有新颖的战斗系统，我还是给出不推荐的评价。

Geneforge 1 is pure, simple perfection, and a large part of my emergence as a gamer. For those liking more story-focused RPG games, it may very well be a hidden gem.

G1 is a testament to how a well-written story will outlast graphical advancements any day, because while graphics become more outdated with time, a good story will last forever. G1 hits you with a curious but well-executed medieval Sci-Fi story, that's simultaneously thoughtful, memorable, and well before it's time. There are no real low points to it either; from start to finish, it remains strong and consistent. You are also very much the master of your own destiny in the game; unlike the future games, which place you into a specific sect as soon as you start the game, G1 has zero hand holding. Beyond the vague reputation of your kind, you're free to do whatever you want, and you can very easily play without allying yourself with the numerous factions presented to you. There's also the option to go completely mad with power, which I personally have a big preference for, and very much appreciate and recommend.

As a small segue from the storyline point, from a graphics perspective, this game is very primitive. That's not to say it's bad by any means; it's very simplistic spritework (which you can actually view frame-by-frame from files in the main data section), which I personally like a lot. But emphasis should be made that it's VERY simplistic, as even when the game first came out, the graphics were considered primitive. If you're someone who prioritizes prettier graphics over storyline, the Geneforge series will not be for you.

Exploration also plays a large role in this game. Beyond finding enemies to kill for XP & loot, and hidden vendors to sell loot too (as vendors have a static amount of buying currency, and you'll very quickly exhaust the main city buyers), you'll find a surprisingly dense amount of lore scattered strategically throughout each map. Enemies are placed in smart locations, traps are both smart & fair, and neither is so oppressive that they cancel each other out; you can very easily do everything and go everywhere in this game, despite what some of the ingame text tries to tell you. I would very much recommend exploring everywhere you find interesting or worthwhile; beyond the aforementioned points about loot & XP, G1 has some of the most memorable map areas of any game I've played to date (Hill of Jars, Shaper Crypt, and Valley of the Wind, to name a few). With that said, you will reach certain level caps where lower-level areas are no longer rewarding enough to explore, which is completely fine, as you can always prioritize them in another playthrough.

Combat is generally simple and well balanced, with positioning and terrain usage/awareness playing key roles in your success or failure (especially on the higher difficulties). Your choice of Shaper (creation user & support mage), Guardian (physical DPS with some creation support), or Agent (magic DPS with some physical options and very limited creation support) will very drastically affect the way you play, with some options being more user friendly than others (in my opinion, Shapers are the easiest to play as, Guardians in the middle, and Agents as the hardest, almost solely due to how well creations do). Unlike some of the future Geneforge games, every class is viable on every difficulty. 

With that said, perhaps one of the very few minorly-negative points I have about G1 is that it's a very offensive-oriented game, though do take in mind that this is most from the perspective of someone that plays solely on Torment difficulty, where taking 2 hits kills you at pretty much every stage of the game. There are no defensive spells, and only one defensive buff exists, which can only be applied with a very rare item set. Furthermore, Anatomy replaces Parry from the future games, so the only option is to pump points into Endurance (which give limited returns), or focus entirely on offensive DPS. As such, melee is theoretically usable but entirely nonviable, and ranging is king. You will live and die on your DPS, positioning, and combat priority. This is also why creations are so good, as they can help supplement in damage (as your own damage will start falling off later on), and tank damage that'd otherwise kill you. With that said, it is entirely natural do die several times during a run, which makes mistakes more forgiving, but kills immersion a bit, as you can run straight into an enemy stronghold to scout out their defenders, than reload and strategically start picking them off (with knowledge you shouldn't have if you were doing everything in one go). With that said, none of these are a real deal breaker, but it does encourage similar play-styles between characters.

As a small aside, I'd like to point out that, while this game uses a die/%-to-hit system, which I find very easy to despise if implemented improperly, G1 executes it well enough that I'm comfortable liking it. Hits can be a bit more variable in the later stages, as several die are cast for attacks & can lead to a 40% variance in damage sometimes, but the game's forgiving enough that it becomes less of a factor (so you don't get the FTL paradox of losing a run because a series of rolls didn't go your way). It also, mercifully, does away with the 95% to-hit cap from the Avernum series games of the same era.

A few veteran tips; if you can handle the responsibility (and not be tempted to exploit the game), holding down Shift + D, and then typing "exitzone" can be used to warp out of towns and dungeons instantly, and hence save a lot of time that'd otherwise be spent backtracking. Likewise, "clearthisarea" can be used to a similar effect. Again though, use these responsibly, as both can break game progression. Secondly, G1 has hands down the best secret of the series, which I think every player should get to experience. Without spoiling the secret itself, start at the special totem in Drake's Vale, than work your way clockwise around the mountain, touching each level's special totem in order (you'll know when you've hit the last one). The rest I'll let you experience for yourself.

In conclusion, Geneforge 1 is one of the closest examples of a perfect game I can think of. It flawlessly merges simple graphics with well-balanced gameplay, and a deep, complex narrative. It offers players with a large, vibrant world to explore, and rewards their efforts with fun challenges & chunks of extra lore. 

Some games don't need to unring a bell...

10/10

TL;DR - A breathtakingly original, open ended, nuanced, ahead of its time, extremely well written sci-fi yarn about people meddling with overwhelming power and the fallout of using it to create living (intelligent and self-aware) tools of servitude wrapped inside a horribly paced, convoluted, imbalanced, frustratingly buggy, puke green shell.

Pacing and balance is the main problem with Geneforge: it takes way too long before anything interesting happens, locations become stale before you get anywhere relevant to the story, enemies and obstacles are painfully repetitious (and lazy- how many freaking maps are nothing but endless turrents/mines put behind every corner and bend)...  the list goes on... talent trees are unforgiving, leveling up is far too grindy (especially after the game stops rewarding you exp for completing quests), core abilites level up purely on random exploration, inventory management is painful, towns are far too big, most abilities are pointless, enemy difficulty goes from too easy to downright stupid so fast you can't even see it, looking for specific quest or story NPCs in the sea of identical NPCs is annoying, save/rest scumming is a core mechanic... you get the idea.

The one redeeming element of Geneforge- and it's pretty bright considering- is the extremely sharp and hauntingly subtle storyline.  The idea of the shaper knowledge changing your persona as you grow in power, putting you on top of several groups all vying for their own freedom in a hopeless situation is expressed with efficient detail (not a word too few or too many).  All the major factions rest in grey areas where you're simultaneously intrigued and repulsed.  Getting the second hand story of everything else happening on Sucia island mirrors your own journey with surreal flavor; you can't help but be taken aback and become invested in the various outcomes.

Unfortunately, even the brightest parts of Geneforge are not without serious issues.  Allying with the different groups doesn't alter the general game in any real way, there are too many strange side factions introduced so late you can't really care, there is way too much back and forth running around, the Geneforge itself is haphazardly shoehorned into the story, the main antagonist is fun to read about but doesn't make an appearance until the end of the game, and again, everything takes way too long.  It might sound as if I'm nit-picking or being overly critical but due to the amount of wasted, pointless time in Geneforge, little annoyances become overwhelming.

I am familiar with Spiderweb Software and yes, such a huge game is an achievement for such a small dev team (in the early 2000's no less).  Moreover, I don't necessarily wish to tarnish Geneforge's positive Steam reception, but reviewing the game has to take into account both the time it was released as well as the time it's currently being played in.  While Geneforge has a wealth of content (something to be noted and prized in the early 2000s) most of it feels stretched thin like too little butter across too much toast.

If you're a fan of early PC western RPGs (ie. Fallout, Baldur's gate, or other Spiderweb games), and you've got the patience, you will most likely enjoy Geneforge (especially for it's story).  If you're not (regardless of what age group you're in), you may not find much to compel you here.

As a longtime fan of Spiderweb games in general, I have to say that Geneforge is by far my favorite. While the gameplay itself is pretty simple, and (let's be honest) quite repetitive. The heart of this game is in its story. Most notably in the moral crux that it presents, which pretty much boils down to:

If you have the power to create and end life with the literal wave of a hand, are you morally obligated to grant your creations any rights that you yourself cannot take away?

Some creations treat you as a god, some see you as an equal, and some hate you because they never asked to be created. It's an interesting and thought-provoking concept that's well worth the price. It feels more like a book than a video game, and that's not a bad thing.

I played all of Geneforge 1 in 2005 or 2006, right around there.  More recently, I bought the game on Steam about 4 years ago and played some of the beginning.  What do I think of it?  It's a good game--I can't deny this.

But in many ways it doesn't even come close when compared with some of the titles I feel to be truly great.  When I played it I compared it specifically to Final Fantasy 6 and Chrono Trigger, and the first Dungeon Siege, which were basically the only RPG's I'd played.  Like most typical RPG's your character increases in strength and abilities by killing enemies and completing quests.  But the classes differ vastly.

Your character can be one of three classes: a Shaper, who specializes in creating living creatures directly from magic; an Agent, who is far more focused on using magic spells to inflict the actual damage; and a Guardian, whose specialty is dealing direct physical damage, mostly with swords.  I tested Shaper and Agent, but in the end enjoyed Guardian much more--the other classes seemed playable, but I think Guardian is easiest from my recollection, and didn't require as much micromanagement.  The gameplay is good, and in combat your character gets action points you can spend to move, fight, and use items and abilities.

Combat makes up a lot of Geneforge, though you'll probably also spend lot of time talking to characters in the game, picking up items and selling them and trying to amass enough money to purchase the best items.

But the best part of the game is the story.  You will learn more about magic, and the Geneforge in particular, a powerful piece of magical machinery that can greatly enhance those who use it properly.  You'll learn about the different magical creations in the game, learn about the different factions in the game (four of them IIRC), and learn about the history of the land you've been stranded in.  And much of the heart of Geneforge is freedom to choose--your character build, your faction, your ending.  If you sufficiently improve your character, you will be able to roll over most enemies.  

Anyway . . . if this review sounds a little bland, perhaps it's because the game itself is kind of bland as well.  There are people who absolutely adore the whole idea of turn-based strategy, the idea of tactically micromanaging the actions of each of your party members, and carefully choosing their equipments and stats.  I used to be one of those people, when I first started playing RPG's, but less so today.  And if you are one of those people--I suspect that you will LOVE Geneforge.

But these days, I suppose I feel I need more from a game.  I think all the micromanagement has gotten to me over the years.  But also, Geneforge has very little atmosphere or enjoyable character.  It has virtually no music, though it does have atmospheric sounds.  I can't remember the name of a single character from Geneforge--whereas I can remember the names of all the main characters from Final Fantasy VI and Chrono Trigger, even though it's been even longer since I played them.  Geneforge's environments are mostly brown--deserts and dirt, though there is some variety thrown in.  And--while the ability to create life in Geneforge is quite awesome--I didn't even feel that this aspect of gameplay was very fleshed-out.  The story in Geneforge is definitely interesting, and there is a huge volume of writing in the game, so if you're a big fan of reading in your games, I can see it appealing to you.  But frankly, I still feel that both FF6 and CT have significantly more interesting stories, characters, environments, and of course excellent music.

Geneforge is a good game.  Some people love it.  You may.  Someday, I may go through and play the others in the series.  But . . . I didn't find a whole lot be excited by in this title, and I feel its impact is far less than it would have been than if, for example, the creator had even expended minimal effort to create a few characters that are really memorable.

7/10

[b]tl;dr:[/b]  If this review is too long for you, you probably aren't going to enjoy this text-heavy game.  But you can skip to the summary at the end.

REVIEW

Go back to the very early stages of this millenium (when this game was released), and you might remember two things:  (1) fascination with emerging medical technologies surrounding genetic modification and (2) the Infinity Engine at its zenith.  Both of these influences can be found in Geneforge, which takes genetic modification as its theme, and uses a Baldur's Gate-like mechanic for its gameplay (although shorn of D&D rules and a conventional fantasy setting).

Like the Infinity Engine games, Geneforge is an isometric, story-driven RPG which actually respects the *R*.  It takes place in several discrete zones spread out over a world map.  It is text-heavy.  The basic mechanics are much simpler here, however--simpler, but complicated enough to admit of sophisticated strategy.  It is also quite robust, giving many hours of gameplay to anyone interested in exploring everything.

As an indie game, however, it is graphically ugly.  Much of the text exists to describe what more graphically advanced games would show without words.  The interface is sometimes incovenient, and you'll naturally find yourself irritated with some of the aspects of inventory management--although my own irritation might have a lot to do with my neurotic hoarding/organizing addiction.  (For a reference, check out some of the screenshots posted in the Steam community to get a sense of how loot can get away with you.)

The open-endedness of the world can also be a curse as much as a blessing:  about halfway through the game, it's easy to lose focus on where you ought to be going.  ([url=https://www.gamefaqs.com/pc/562951-geneforge/faqs/16837]There's a nice FAQ out there, however, which can help out.[/url] If nothing else, check out the Matt P's numeric rating of the difficulty of each zone--this can give you a sense of what areas are best to tackle next.)

To my mind, there are two main selling points to this game: (1) the novelty of creating and modifying creatures to aid you as you go about, and more importantly (2) the story.  But the attractiveness of the story needs some unpacking.

The story is open-ended, and it involves you responding to some events on an island surrounding competing factions with conflicting motivations vying for power.  That's nice and all--although you can get that kind of fare elsewhere.  That's not where the real juice of this game lies.  The best part of the story isn't the plot proper, which concerns your character.  It's what has already happened in the *past*, and which you discover incrementally as you proceed.

Think of yourself as a kind of archeologist, doing a dig.  You dig at a site, and discover what a certain society was like.  But if you dig a bit deeper, you might see the remains of a civilization that existed at an even earlier time.  Dig even deeper and...you get the idea.  The way I counted, there were *four* layers of history contained in this game, from the truly ancient to the recent past, and you fill in the pieces of this rich puzzle of what has happened on Sucia Island as you proceed.  (Incidentally, I have no idea if this pattern continues for other games in this saga, although I suspect not.)

If the idea of playing the role of archeologist sounds like your cup of tea, pick up this game.  (You might also want to pick up Steven Erikson's fantasy novels, but I digress.)

For me, [u]Geneforge[/u] is one of the series that represents a hybrid of old school and new for RPG, a transition that came around at a time when developers not only relied on certain conventions (such as the heavy use of textual description in games) but embraced these over the flash and thunder of visual & audio spectacle that would inevitably supplant them in mainstream gaming.  This review is for Geneforge 1 through 5, the complete series.

  Mr. Jeff Vogel and his [i]Spiderweb Software[/i] are involved not just in the Geneforge IP but also the [u]Avernum[/u] series which is enjoyable.  Geneforge was developed in five installments from 2001 to 2008.  Graphics were never a priority with this IP, and in my opinion like most games developed by this company, its greatest strength is story.

Some things that must be talked about when discussing Geneforge:
[list]
    [*]Heavy use of text
    [*]Merciless combat & careful character progression
    [*]No hand holding or linearity in a huge world
[/list]
  Understand that these games feel old by any standard.  People who didn't grow up playing MUDs or other types of games in high school will likely be frustrated by the high amount of text here: it's how you get the dialogue, interact with people and objects, and absorb specific information about every new area you come across in addition to most of the situations that dynamically arise in the game world.  The pace of the game is necessarily slowed down by this feature and many players either don't have the patience or simply aren't inclined to sit through so much content when presented in this format.  Yeah, you have to stop and read.  I urge you to take that time and effort, since the reading provides great detail and insight into the lore, characters and story --not to mention you'll be completely lost on what to do next if you skip through it!

  Combat can be very fun and is especially rewarding after you've repeated an encounter that initially punished you but discovered a viable path to victory.  "Shaping," the act of creating life via magic, is the central theme of Geneforge and translates into an "essence" mechanic, a second mana pool the player character spends to summon a host of little minions (or a handful of stronger ones, or a single powerful one; it varies based on the demands of each encounter).  There are a few types of shaping that each come with their own creations (magical, melee, ranged, control, etcetera).  Even on the casual difficulty you need to be smart about how you invest skill points upon leveling up.  Support skills like Leadership and Mechanics are great; they can supposedly be used to beat the game without a combat-viable character.  Melee and ranged specializations are available too, of course, if you aren't into the magic system.  I found the most success with a bit of everything, emphasizing survivability + stats over armor in my gear choices.  Be prepared for some trial and error (or look up some cheats online...but really, don't do that).  There are a couple of succinct and helpful guides out there, though.

  The third item on that list just further drives home the importance of realizing it's a long game with lots of text.  You have very little indication of where to go or what to do even when given a quest.  You'll forge out into the world and earn every inch of progress with meticulous interrogation of NPCs in towns and navigation of treacherous, trap-filled monster infested wildlands in equal measure.  If you skip that text, eventually you'll be having to consult a guide or just roam randomly until you get lucky.  I did not explore every area, complete every quest, hunt down every rare item or talk to everyone I met.  In fact, at times I followed the main questline as closely as is possible in my eagerness to see the main plot play out.  

  Technically the game is very simple but runs without any issue.  It started as demoware on the Mac.  Everything runs fine but looks extremely dated and perhaps feels clunky.  

  The themes dealt with in this story are ones I liked and would enjoy seeing more of in future games.  I found it very pleasing that the story unfolded in episodic manner from one game to the next, especially regarding the recurring characters who I'd grown attached to.  The only criticism I'd level against the story is that it is delivered almost too arbitrarily; I felt at times I would have been better served experiencing the story through my actions rather than being told what to think with a text box.  Overall however, it was an excellent delivery.  Of the cRPGs I've played, this series isn't my favorite but it's up there, although...

  I can only recommend Geneforge to players who have considerable patience and time on their hands for the experience I've described above, and who are craving an "old school" game.  It's challenging but good fun.  Defeating your enemies to reach the ending and see how everything wraps up based on your choices is so rewarding.

TIP: Be thorough in exploring, talking, and reading the text for each area.  It'll help in various ways, not just the extra experience points.
TIP: Guides exist online if you find yourself in an unbeatable fight or unsure of where to go next.

Combat is turn-based, and on the surface, can be quite tactical. Timing, and awareness of the positions of both your allies and your enemies are all quite important.
